title: theresa may housing policy election
story: There are all kinds of answers.A social care policy that went down among elderly Tory voters like a cup of cold novichok.A leader who repeated the phrase “strong and stable” so much the record started to scratch.But the statistics tell a simpler story — they lost it because of HOUSING.The voters who drove Labour’s turnout surge were those who used to be able to own homes, but now can’t.This “rentquake”, according to pollster Matt Singh, was enough to explain 77 per cent of the swing to Labour.These young voters are furious. And they’re right to be.As recently as 1991, a third of those aged 16 to 24 owned their own home.Now, that figure is ten per cent.For those aged 25 to 34, the rate has fallen from 66 per cent to 38 per cent.Home ownership rates in Britain are now the fourth lowest in the EU, and we have the second highest proportion of social housing, i.e., people living in homes provided by the State.Earlier this year, we at the Centre for Policy Studies commissioned polling asking young people how government could make their lives better.The top answer was clear — they want housing to be more affordable.And not via cheaper rents — by a three-to-one margin, they wanted the Government to prioritise home ownership.Strikingly, only three per cent of those aged 18 to 24 told us they never wanted to own their own home.They just can’t see themselves being able to afford it for years — often decades.This is a crisis with many causes.The persistent failure, stretching back decades, to build enough new homes. A dysal planning system.Existing homeowners who don’t want their communities disrupted or their views spoiled.A Labour government that made it much easier for buy-to-let landlords to snap up those homes that were being built, and much harder for first-time buyers to do the same — and a financial crash which made that problem so much worse. Yet it’s also a crisis with many solutions.Making it easier to extend or expand existing properties. Changing Green Belt regulations so we protect our most beautul countryside while building on pig farms, or beside railway stations or motorways or electricity substations or other decidedly non-green and unpleasant bits of land.Finding ways  to turn renters into owners, as Margaret Thatcher did with the Right to Buy for council tenants in the 1980s, with more than a little success.But the sad truth is that while the Government has succeeded in dragging up construction levels, it is still not thinking anywhere near radically enough.“Since my very first day in Downing Street, I have made it my personal mission to fix our broken housing system,” Theresa May told the National Housing Federation yesterday.But that mission is in grave jeopardy.A year ago, the Prime Minister endured a triple whammy of embarrassment in her party conference speech — being handed a P45 by a prankster, developing a crippling cough, then seeing the slogan behind her start to fall off.Mrs May bravely endured these trials. But she could do little about the fact that her promise in the same speech to “make the British dream a reality by igniting home ownership once again” was built around a £10billion expansion of the Help to Buy scheme.A scheme which pretty much every economist, including the Government’s own Office for Budget Responsibility, says is mostly serving to push up house prices and make colossally rich housebuilders even richer.Indeed, even as Mrs May was speaking, their collective share price spiked by £1BILLION.Yesterday, the Prime Minister ed to the subject.In a speech to the National Housing Summit, she promised another £2billion for social housing.But even on its own terms, Mrs May’s proposal isn’t a blunderbuss.It’s a pinprick. Not only is the £2billion spread over a decade but it’s a small fraction of the amount that George Osborne cut from the same budgets.And it fits a wider pattern. For all the Government’s rhetoric, the big ideas to get Britain building just aren’t there.One of the keys to David Cameron’s election victory in 2015 — right there on the first page of the Tory manesto — was a promise to extend the Right to Buy to housing associations and to build 200,000 starter homes.The commitment was to create two million more homeowners within five years.As of May 2018, not a single one of those starter homes had been built — and the expansion of Right to Buy is still lodged in the gullet of the Whitehall machine.It’s the same pattern on planning reform.Sajid Javid’s robust proposals as Communities Secretary to break up the oligopoly of the big housebuilders, free up more land and speed up development — all badly needed — were neutered by Downing Street, because it was paranoid about upsetting traditional Tory voters who don’t like the sight of bulldozers.When the Government’s new planning framework was announced in March, the headlines were about building more and higher-quality homes.But the small print made it so that councils could get away with building fewer houses, not more.I don’t doubt that Mrs May’s heart is in the right place.But  she and her team don’t pluck up their courage on housing — and take far more dramatic steps both to build more houses and create more homeowners — they’ll almost certainly lose the next election. More than that, they’ll deserve to.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: rod liddle immigration post brexit
story: Immigration. A vexed issue. Complain about it and people will call you a racist.That’s a popular way of shutting down debate these days. Just screech “raaacisst” at someone.I’d go so far as to say it’s one of the reasons Leave won the referendum — because ordinary people were sick of being called racist when they simply worried about the millions of people who have arrived here in the past ten years.About seven million, in fact. An astonishing number.The Prime Minister is about to draw up her plans for immigration post-Brexit.She will be taking advice from the Migration Advisory Committee . It has suggested we allow in skilled workers who might be vital to our economy.It has also suggested we clamp down on low-skilled migrants.This seems to me a perfectly sensible argument. We should not entirely close ourselves off from the world. And there are foreign nationals here who do excellent work for our country. And pay good taxes.At the same time, the vast influx of low-skilled workers has had a terrible effect upon our country.Some towns — such as Boston in Lincolnshire — have been effectively taken over.And as the MAC found, the vast reservoir of labour has depressed the wages of British people at the lowest end of the scale. It has hurt the poorest of us.But it doesn’t only hurt us. You’ll have seen the squalid conditions in which a lot of these low-paid foreign workers live. This is exploitation, on a massive scale.How any leftie can support it absolutely befoggles me.Living below the minimum wage, crammed into rotten accommodation — all so companies such as Amazon can make a bigger profit.No wonder the big companies were the first to complain. Listen: Pay your workers a decent, living wage in future and shut up, huh?But this is an overcrowded country. It is ludicrous to suggest that the millions we have allowed in have not had a massive effect on our infrastructure.It’s why we need to pave over more and more of the countryside to build homes, for example. The MAC suggested house prices had risen as a consequence — and our homes already cost too much.There’s pressure on our schools, our hospitals and our transport networks.Well, with any luck this will all come to an end. Perhaps the Government might also abide by its pledge to get yearly immigration levels down to the tens of thousands, rather than the hundreds of thousands as it is at the moment.But at the same time we should look after the EU migrants we have already let in, and ensure they feel secure and safe living in Britain.Do all that and I’ll be a happy man. Even  the lefties still shriek “raaacisst” every few seconds.GIRLS – looking for something to wear for a night out? You’ll find it in a drawer in your kitchen.They come in rolls for about £1.50 from Asda. Yep, it’s the black bin liner, as sported here by Megan Barton Hanson.I have no idea, incidentally, who Megan Barton Hanson is, still less her boyfriend called “Wes”.BBC Radio 6 presenter Cerys Matthews says she refuses to play music made by people who went to private school.OK, Cerys. That means your entire back catalogue is banned, seeing as you were educated at the expensive St Michael’s School in Llanelli.A few weeks ago a BBC executive said he wouldn’t be commissioning comedies from public schoolboys .Spouting every right-on opinion that suddenly swings into fashion?Here’s a tip, Cerys. Play the best rock, folk and soul music you can find.The stuff that sounds the most interesting.You’ll find that auto- matically the private school musicians will be excluded anyway – including yourself.APPARENTLY President Trump’s penis closely resembles a toadstool.This is according to Stormy Daniels, who says she had an affair with Donald.The question is, though – what kind of toadstool?There are hundreds of thousands of species. Was it a fly agaric? That’s the one with a big red head covered in white spots. If so, Donald ought to get himself to a doctor.Or maybe it’s that one with a thin stalk and a big yellow head the size of a dinner plate.If so, Stormy had better get herself to a doctor.A “RELATIONSHIP expert” has warned us all about dodgy body language  we’re out on a date.Tracey Cox says we shouldn’t fidget, for a start. What, even  we’ve taken her to a ballet?Also, don’t wring your hands or sit in a slumped manner, and so on.Hmm. As a “relationship expert” I offer the following advice to blokes out on a first date in a restaurant.2. Don’t pass wind then waft the air saying “Mmmmm, Bisto!”3. When they bring the black pepper, don’t sneeze on her pasta.4. If you do sneeze on her pasta, stir it around a bit when she’s not looking.5. Don’t use a bread stick to excavate the contents of your ear.6. Don’t keep checking the football scores on your phone. And shouting loudly: “Lee Gregory! 85th minute! Get IN you f***er!”7. Don’t ask the lady at the next table  she’s up for a threesome.Follow that stuff and you can fidget away to your heart’s delight. You’ll be OK.THERE’S a crisis in our wildle. Some of our favourite species of birds or mammals are on the brink of extinction.The corn bunting, for example, and the hedgehog.As TV wildle campaigner Chris Packham rightly says, this is because we have paved over the countryside to build ever more homes.And because of the intensive farming methods – which have seen the eradication of farmland birds.Packham has drawn up a “People’s Manesto for Wildle” which includes stuff like twinning city schools with farms, so that kids grow up with an understanding of nature.There’s also a demo at Hyde Park in London on Saturday. I’ll be there. Don’t forget – as Joni Mitchell once sang, you don’t know what you’ve got ’til its gone.SO, it looks very much as  the old Irish border problem is going to be solved very quickly after all.We’re close to agreeing a deal with the European Union which will enable Northern Ireland to retain its “soft border”.The Remainers said it couldn’t be done. Totally impossible. But  we don’t want a hard border and the Irish don’t want a hard border – who is going to make us have one?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: high speed hose treat prostate
story: It shoots a saline solution guided by a robot into the prostate in minutes rather than the patient having to spend a night in hospital.Millions of older men commonly struggle with a condition known as benign prostate hypertrophy — causing problems with urinating.The prostate gland becomes enlarged and presses on the tube that takes urine from the bladder.The speedy new hose treatment could bring relief to many sufferers.Guidance published by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence said: “This procedure uses a specialised system for the targeted heat-free removal of prostate tissue with the patient under general or spinal anaesthesia. “A probe is inserted through the urethra and into the bladder where its position is confirmed using a computer.”It added: “The old procedure normally involved an overnight stay in hospital.”Clinical trials for the “hosepipe” are still on-going and more evidence will be available about the treatment next year, but currently its not widely available on the NHS.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gas safety week parents tragic girl
story: Without regular checks and servicing, a boiler or any other gas appliance could leak toxic carbon monoxide – putting you and your family’s lives at risk.To mark Gas Safety Week, three readers speak to LYNSEY HOPE about their boiler disasters. They are urging you to get yours serviced and to install audible carbon monoxide monitors in your home.It might just save a le.Schoolgirl Katie Overton went to bed excited about her little sister’s birthday party next day — but tragically the family never got to celebrate.The next morning, the 11-year-old was found dead in her bed, having been poisoned by carbon monoxide which had leaked from a faulty boiler at her home.Stepdad Paul recalls: “We’d been busy getting ready for Emma’s fth birthday party. We’d been baking cakes and blowing up balloons.“We went to bed as normal that night. In the morning we all got up and cracked on with the arrangements and we thought Katie was having a lie-in.“The house seemed very quiet. I popped out and when I came home, Katie still wasn’t up.“We were used to her having a lie-in at the weekend, but we felt something was wrong.”Mum Debra, 47, went up to Katie’s bedroom at the family’s rented terraced house in Southsea, Hants.Paul, 53, recalls: “Debs called out to me that she’d been sick in her bed. I ran upstairs and she was lying there, motionless.“I started shaking her, trying to rouse her. She wasn’t responding. Her body was cold.“I told Debs to call 999 and I spoke to paramedics on the phone. They told me to try mouth-to-mouth, but her jaw was locked. I knew then she was dead.“We had no idea why or what had happened. All of us were in a state of shock.”An ambulance rushed Katie to Queen Alexandra Hospital in Portsmouth, but within half an hour a doctor confirmed the family’s worst fears.Paul says: “He said there was nothing they could do for her. There was no obvious cause of death.“All we could think was that she’d been sick in her sleep and choked on it.“Because it was an unexplained death, we had CID come to the house. They asked us all sorts of questions, whether Katie had been having any problems at school.“They took away the mattress as evidence and the four of us were left in the house, with no idea the gas was still leaking.”To make matters even worse, rumours circulated around the area that Paul and Debra had murdered their daughter.Paul says: “A friend of Debra’s told us there were some lies going around. There was a lot of stares and whispering behind our backs.“It was incredibly hard to deal with, as we were grieving for Katie.“We were in a state of shock. She was a perfectly healthy girl and she seemed fine when she went to bed the night before.”Post-mortems do not routinely check for carbon monoxide poisoning, so no cause of death was given to her family.But around ten days later, Debra woke Paul early one morning complaining of a strong smell of fumes.He recalls: “I had a splitting headache and the house stank. I felt dizzy and sick.“I phoned our letting agent and said we thought something was seriously wrong with the boiler. An engineer came out and said he was going to put a carbon monoxide monitor by the boiler and we all had to leave the house. He left it running for ten minutes before going back in to grab it. He ran back out again and said, ‘I can’t believe any of you are alive.’“There was a lethal amount of carbon monoxide in the house. He kept saying he was surprised we were still alive.“I asked him  he thought it might have caused Katie’s death and he said, ‘Possibly’.” Paul phoned the police and even though Katie’s body had been cremated, they still had some blood samples. They later tested positive for carbon monoxide.An investigation revealed that faulty pipework on the boiler had been allowing the toxic gas to escape into Katie’s bedroom. Paul has been campaigning for tighter regulations to prevent deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning ever since Katie’s death in March 2003.She says: “He seemed very poorly. He didn’t have a temperature but he kept falling asleep and he’d vomit.“Then, I’d find him asleep in the dining room in a really strange position. Something just didn’t feel right.”The same morning, the carbon monoxide alarm at her home in Strood, Kent, started beeping. She says: “It wasn’t the continuous warning alarm but it was beeping as  it had run out of batteries.“I guess it just made me think and I had a niggling feeling it might be something to do with carbon monoxide. I rushed Aaden-James to A&ampE. They took a blood sample and within five minutes he was on oxygen. He had to spend a couple of days in hospital.“Fortunately, he is OK and there are no lasting effects.”Tests later revealed the gas was leaking from pipes at the top of the boiler.Kirstein says: “If you don’t have a carbon monoxide alarm, get one now. I had one before, now I have three.”But latest figures show there are still around 50 fatalities a year in the UK.He says: “Fteen years on and the basic laws haven’t changed and people are still dying.“Katie’s death was preventable. We didn’t have a carbon monoxide alarm in the house.“We are all now living with a sadness that will never go away.”Paul adds that the tragedy has been particularly hard on Katie’s sisters, Sian, now 22, and Emma, 21.He says: “We want to make people aware of the dangers of carbon monoxide so no more families lose someone like we have.“Sometimes people will say to me, ‘It’s OK, I haven’t got gas, I’ve got a wood-burning stove.’“But carbon monoxide is produced by all solid fuels that burn. There are more carbon monoxide alarms around now than when Katie died, but in England, the law says they only have to be in properties that burn solid fuel.THE Sun is offering you the chance to win one of five brand new Ariston boilers worth more than £1,000 each.The Ariston Clas Net ONE comes with an industry-leading 12-year warranty.To be in with a chance of winning see thesun/aristoncompetition and answer two simple questions.“In Scotland, they have to be in all properties. The law in England needs changing — everyone should have one.“What about older properties? They often don’t have alarms. And what about your neighbour? We lived in a terraced house — the people next door may well have been poisoned as well.“Carbon monoxide goes straight through the brickwork. Please make sure you install an audible alarm in your home. If we’d had one, we would have been alerted to the gas and our beautul Katie would still be with us.”Paul also warns that gas safety ­certicates are not a substitute for ­having appliances regularly serviced.He says: “You can get a certicate without having a service. Of course, a lot of people choose this asSue, 45, had moved into a new-build home in Sale, Grt Manchester, with son Josh and now ex-husband Paul in 2003.She says: “I worked at home running a building firm. I’d get headaches and be queasy, dizzy and fatigued. I put it down to stress. I was forgetful, but thought I was getting dementia. Josh was six. He’d get stomach and head pains.Three years later, Sue was admitted to hospital TWICE with chest pain – and once collapsed – but each time doctors misdiagnosed cocaine abuse, let her rest then discharged her.“No one mentioned carbon monoxide and I wasn’t tested,” she says. But the warranty on her boiler then expired and Paul called an engineer, who found the leaky flue under the lounge floor.Sue still suffers memory, migraine and rheumatic trouble while Josh has poor concentration, and she thinks her family only survived because Paul would open windows a lot. She warns: “With smoke you get a warning but with CO there is no taste or smell. It is a silent killer.”“But what it means is that all these years after Katie’s death, an engineer can walk into a house, have a look at the flame and say, ‘Yes it’s burning a nice blue and it is safe.’“It gives you a false confidence. All gas appliances need to be serviced as per the manufacturers’ guidelines.“And get it done now, don’t wait until November when engineers are busy. It could save a le.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: sun says housing revolution
story: The latest cash injection is derisory.The Government is trumpeting £2billion of new funding for housing associations over six years from 2022. That’s just 7,000 homes a year nationwide.Our population is increasing by almost 400,000 a year. The annual ­target for new homes is 300,000 — and we doubt even that would lower prices enough for young people to afford to buy in London and the South East.In fairness, the total HAS risen to 217,000 a year, the most since 2007. But it’s still way short — and the Government’s remedies are woefully timid.Sajid Javid promised a huge shake-up when he ran housing. He was knocked back by the negativity from Philip Hammond’s Treasury. Then he moved on.We need to slash planning restrictions and defy obstructive NIMBYs. We need to stop the land-banking that sees developers hoard plots or release homes at a snail’s pace to keep prices high.We need more cash help for small builders. We should borrow billions, build affordable homes on public land and sell them at a profit for the Treasury.The Tories need to wake up or housing will sink them. Instead they are hyping up some footling new funding that only partly reverses a previous cut.It fools no one.WHY is the EU wasting time pressing for a border between Britain and Northern ­Ireland? It’s a non-starter.No Government could consider it. Especially not one entirely reliant on the votes of those most vehemently opposed to splitting up the UK, the DUP.This cannot be news to Brussels. They cannot believe Theresa May will surrender and collapse her Government.Why persist with it? The answer must be: to run down the clock — until, at the last minute, Mrs May agrees virtually anything to avoid a No Deal.Which is why Donald Tusk also still insists key areas of our wildly over-generous Chequers offer must be “reworked”.Mrs May has gone as far as she can. Two Cabinet figures have quit already. She must insist it’s take it or leave it.Only Britain has made genuine compromises in this negotiation, as despondent Brexiteers know only too well.It’s the EU’s turn.FROM child abuse images to terrorism, Facebook is a platform for evil it seems unable or unwilling to prevent.Now it is hosting ads for people- smuggling gangs luring children to their doom in the Mediterranean.A new low, even for a tech giant with apparently no moral compass.Since Facebook now admits it is a publisher, why isn’t it regulated as one?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dup ian paisley keeps seat recall petition
story: The North Antrim DUP politician, who is helping to prop up Theresa May, was suspended for failing to declare two holidays paid for by the Sri Lankan government.He narrowly avoided a by-election after fewer than 10 per cent of constituents signed the petition.The petition device, created in the wake of the Westminster expenses scandal, was initiated after Mr Paisley was banned from the House of Commons over his South Asian holidays.A parliamentary watchdog found in July that a year after the trips, Mr Paisley lobbied then prime minister David Cameron not to support a UN probe into alleged Sri Lankan human rights abuses.In a statement, Mr Paisley last night said: In July I apologised for a mistake made almost six years ago.The electorate was asked to pass judgement. 90.6% have accepted my apology. The electorate has clearly spoken.I would like to thank my true friends, family, the electorate who have stood by me with unwavering support. Hallelujah.The long-standing Democratic Unionist, whose late father the Reverend Ian Paisley founded the party, is currently suspended from the DUP pending its own internal investigation into his conduct.Northern Irelands Chief Electoral Officer Virginia McVea announced the outcome in Belfast around 1.25am this morning after a count that commenced at midnight.Ulster Unionist leader Robin Swann said it was clear there was no public appetite for a by-election, saying he respected that outcome.He added: However I would caution Ian Paisley not to see this as some sort of victory or endorsement of his actions in acting as a paid advocate for a foreign government and bringing North Antrim and the House of Commons into disrepute.Rather I would urge him to use the time that he has been suspended from Parliament and the DUP, to reflect on the severity of what he has done and the embarrassment he has brought on Northern Ireland. He should demonstrate some humility.Mr Paisleys Commons ban has left Theresa May shorn of one of her 10 DUP MP confidence and supply allies during a period that could witness several crucial Brexit votes.An investigation by the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards found the cost of the hospitality afforded Mr Paisley and his family may have been signicantly more than his £50,000 estimate.It found the Sri Lankan holidays included business-class air travel, accommodation at first-class hotels, helicopter trips and visits to tourist attractions for the North Antrim MP and his wider family.The trips also included meeting with Sri Lankan governmental figures.Mr Paisleys threshold for registering such hospitality in 2013 was around £660.

title: van driver soaks schoolboy driving through puddle storm ali
story: The clip - filmed yesterday as deadly Storm Ali caused chaos in the UK - was posted on Twitter with the caption: Get back to class ya wet wipe.”It shows the driver pulling out at a junction before driving straight towards a large brown puddle at the side of the road.He then speeds up after seeing three young boys with backpacks on just inches from the puddle.One, who appears to be aged around 15, can be seen trying to shield himself as the water completely drenches him.The Ford driver then laughs before the video - believed to be filmed in Edinburgh - cuts out.The clip was uploaded by @pammy_caton to Twitter yesterday afternoon where it has since attracted over 162,000 views.The 22-year-old electrician has since received dozens of messages trolling him - although at no point does he admit being behind the wheel.One Twitter user, @staceyjaxx451, wrote: “Thats real clever…”@stevieberwick said: “What a c***y thing to do. Honestly people like you shouldn’t be allowed a license. Maniac.”@lewcur28 wrote: “What a pity your f****** vehicle didnt blow up.”@LTCTID said: “If the old bill wanted to they could prosecute you for this as its classed as dangerous driving.”Motorists who drive through puddles and splash nearby pedestrians could be slapped with a £5,000 fine under section three of the Road Traffic Act 1988.It states that it is an offence to drive without reasonable consideration for other persons and according to the Crown Prosecution Service, this includes an instance of driving through a puddle causing pedestrians to be splashed.

title: explorer discovers murals untouched since drawn on wwii air raid shelter
story: Chris Halliwell from Rochdale says he’s stumbled across the coal sketches of women and soldiers from the 1940s – but he’s refused to reveal their location.The 31-year-old was stunned after discovering portraits of women with stylish pin curls believed to have been drawn by workers at a nearby coal plant.He said: “There were a lot of portraits of women and a few men – one that had a pipe in his mouth and another with a rle on his back. It was amazing.”Rumours of the drawings persuaded the self-proclaimed ‘urban explorer’ to spend three days identying the mile-long tunnels.“I thought I knew what to expect and I’d seen a few photos but once I got down there it was a whole dferent story.”As well as the portraits, old gas lamps, barrels used as chemical toilets and kettles were also found rotting away.Cigarette lighter writing on the roof indicated to the bunker’s use in 1942 and 1943, and Chris believes it may have begun as a crisis trench in 1938.The father of four claimed he will keep its location secret to avoid vandalism.He added: “I want to protect it, it’s a piece of history.”Millions sheltered in bunkers like this during heavy enemy bombing in the Blitz which killed 43,000 Brits.That figure includes 684 killed during the 1940 Christmas Blitz in Greater Manchester, where Chris and his family live.Over 600 secret bunkers were also built by the government during the war that lasted from 1939 to 1945.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu bitterly divided on whether to compromise with theresa may on brexit as leaders scrutinise chequers plan without her at crunch summit
story: The Prime Minister insisted her plan was the only credible idea on the table - just minutes after the EUs Donald Tusk insisted it wont work.On day two of a European heads of government meeting in Salzberg, Mrs May stuck to her guns and said again that hers was the only option that could deliver for everyone.She said she had a frank talk with EU leaders, but insisted she was negotiating hard to try and get a deal despite the set-backs.An irritated Mrs May insisted that plans for the Irish border cannot ide the UK into two territories and she would never accept that, but admitted there was just weeks left to come to a deal.However, Mr Tusk told reporters at a press conference just a few minutes earlier: There are positive elements in Chequers, but this adjusted framework for economic cooperation will not work.In a brutal take-down this afternoon, the European Council boss insisted that the PMs ideas would tear apart the blocs principles, and they would not accept them.In two extraordinary press conferences this afternoon:It was hoped that there would be some warm words for the Prime Minister ahead of her party conference next week, but todays outright dismissal of her plans will raise Brexiteer hopes that she will ditch her hated Chequers plans.Last night Mrs May warned them her deal was the only way forward, and she would not delay our EU exit in any circumstances.The standoff over the Irish border comes after deep splits emerged today within the EU over how to deal with Brexit.Some reports say that a rebel group led by the Netherlands and Belgium - and backed by European Council President Mr Tusk - are more keen to compromising with Britain over our EU exit.But Michel Barnier, along with the leaders of France and Germany, are standing firm in their positions on the Irish border.Today President Macron insisted: We have to remain united and consistent with what we want.. what we need is an agreement with the backstop for our Irish friends.But Mrs May demanded yesterday the EU drop their hardline demands on the border in Ireland, telling them that it would effectively ide up the UK and keep Northern Ireland in the bloc after we leave.Irish PM Leo Varadkar, who Mrs May met with this morning, said the EU was very united around our view that we need to protect the integrity of the single market.However, Hungarian leader Viktor Orban said he wasnt part of the group in the bloc which believed the EU should punish Britain.He said: The other camp of prime ministers they would like to deliver evidence that to make that kind of decision is to be punished and the British must suffer. I don’t like that approach at all. What we need is a fair Brexit and good cooperation between UK and EU in future.Jean Claude Juncker appeared to be on the fence, telling reporters that Mrs Mays 10-minute speech at dinner was polite, it was not aggressive, she was doing her job.This morning Mrs May had meetings with other leaders - including Angela Merkel and a series of other leaders.Mr Tusk this morning posted a sassy snap on his Instagram of him offering the PM a bit of cake, with the caption: A piece of cake, perhaps? Sorry, no cherries.TWO EU leaders have spoken out and demanded Brits change their minds and reverse Brexit today.Ahead of Theresa Mays crunch summit in Salzburg, the PMs of Malta and the Czech Republic took the unusual step of calling for a fresh referendum on leaving the EU.Ignoring the clear will of the 17million Brits who opted to break free of the bloc in 2016, Andrej Babiš, the eurosceptic Czech prime minister, told the BBC he was “very unhappy that the UK is leaving and maybe it would be better to make another referendum”.And Joseph Muscat, the Maltese PM, said most of the other EU leaders agreed, and wanted to make the almost impossible happen.I think most of us would welcome a situation where there is the possibility of the British people, putting things into perspective, and then deciding once and for all, he added.But last night the PM told EU leaders there was not going to be another vote.Brussels wants an operational backstop in place to prevent a so-called hard border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland after Brexit.But that would effectively keep Northern Ireland in the EUs single market and customs union.Theresa May simply wont accept this because it will effectively break up the UK and put a virtual border in the Irish sea.And it will infuriate her coalition partners, the DUP, too, who she relies on to win votes in the House of Commons.A new plan by Mr Barnier – revealed by The Sun on Saturday – to police the new customs border between Britain and Northern Ireland with invisible technology has also been thrown out by No10.Britain wants an agreement to not be needed, by agreeing a close partnership with the EU which would make the backstop void.EX-Brexit Secretary David Davis has taken apart Theresa Mays Chequers proposals - on the same day the EU met to discuss them.Mr Davis, who quit over Mrs Mays blueprint for our EU exit, tore them to shreds in a speech today.He told an audience: Chequers is devoid of democracy altogether.Telling Brits they must seize this historic opportunity, he argued that Chequers destroyed all the manesto promises Mrs May had made on taking back control of our money, borders and laws.And he lashed out over plans to keep us tied to the EU forever by accepting a common rulebook.We cannot be governed by a body that we have no control over. It should not even be contemplated, he added.Mr Davis, who is bringing forward an alternative Free Trade Agreement plan in the coming weeks, said Chequers was unpopular among the public too.And on the tricky issue of the Northern Ireland border - which is a huge sticking point in the talks - he insisted there would not be a hard border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland after we leave - because EU politicians have said they wont put one up.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: worker taken out by her own stop and go sign as 100mph storm ali winds battered britain
story: The staff member was crossing the road with a traffic sign when they were swept off their feet as 100mph gusts hit yesterday.They can be seen struggling with the large sign while wearing a high-vis jacket and fluorescent trousers.But after crossing the road safely, the worker is lted off the ground by a ferocious gust of wind.They then comes crashing back down to the wet floor with their own sign hitting them in the face.The footage was posted on Twitter yesterday by Toni Irons with the caption: @ladbible up on the great orme north wales today.It has since been viewed more than 34,000 times and liked by 76 people.Viewers have expressed sympathy for the worker on social media.@LouieZx6r wrote: Welcome to autumn in our north wales.While @NatalieCollett said: No way Toni that is grim haha x.Storm Ali yesterday wreaked havoc on the UK and Ireland with monster winds causing travel chaos and leaving more than 132,000 without power.Two people were killed in the storm - a Swiss tourist died after the caravan she was sleeping in was blown over a clf near Clfden in Co Galway.And an engineer, aged in his 20s, was then killed by a falling tree in Slieve Gullion Forest Park in Newry, Northern Ireland.The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning today for rain and wind as new Storm Bronagh sweeps across the UK.

title: jeremy corbyn demanded a boycott of his own football team arsenal for advertising holidays to israel
story: The Labour leader and Arsenal super fan spoke out against the North London club’s deal with the Israel tourist board during a Palestine Solidarity campaign conference in 2006.The revelation will do nothing to help the embattled leader deal with the party’s anti-Semitism crisis ahead of their annual conference in Liverpool next week.The deal, which was worth £350,000, was approved by Emirates airline, Arsenals main sponsor, before going ahead.According to MailOnline Mr Corbyn said: “We must campaign against and boycott Arsenal football club for their arrangement with the Israeli tourist board.“It is wrong to treat both parties [Israel and Palestine] as equals. The situation is the running sore of US foreign policy.”The Labour boss, who was a backbencher at the time, appeared at the conference which also listed as a speaker preacher Daud Abdullah, who led a boycott of Holocaust Memorial Day.In response Gideon Falter, chairman of the Campaign Against Anti-Semitism, said: “Jeremy Corbyns obsession with Israel blinds him.“He has called for a boycott of his own football club, not because of its close association with the Emirates – which engages in torture and execution – but because of some obscure connection to Israel.”Mr Corbyn, who has often spoken of his love for Arsenal, appeared in a “show racism the red card” video at the club’s ground.But it was mired in controversy after it was revealed the YouTube star interviewing him, David Vujanic, sent tweets containing the N-word and joked about Jews and Hitler.A Labour spokesman responded to MailOnline saying: “Jeremy has never boycotted an Arsenal game.“He does support targeted action aimed at illegal settlements and the occupation of Palestinian territories, and has backed campaigns to bring it to an end.Arsenal football club declined to comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leading labour politician revealed to be advising remainer campaign how to delay brexit and hold second referendum to keep us in the eu
story: Richard Corbett, who sits on the party’s ruling executive and leads their group of MEPs in the European Parliament, is on the “advisory committee” for the People’s Vote.It has produced a paper, which launched this week, explicitly stating that when it comes to exiting the EU, “the die is not irrevocably cast, there is still time and, until the UK has left the EU, the Article 50 letter can be withdrawn”.Mr Corbett’s support for a second referendum adds weight to the idea Labour are set to back another referendum.A series of key figures have softened their stance in recent weeks, including Mr Corbyn himself, his Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell and the Deputy Leader Tom Watson.Another who has said holding a second vote and disregarding the 17 million who backed Brexit two years ago is “an option”, is Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer.He has described Mr Corbett as “effectively a member of my shadow team”, and the MEP has boasted about how he is a de facto member of the Shadow Cabinet, helping to shape party policy.The “Roadmap to a People’s Vote” paper also lists the pro-Remain former minister Dominic Grieve, Labour MP Chris Leslie and ex-Green Party leader Caroline Lucas, who all want to hold a second referendum.The group claims it has found six chances for Britain to have a new vote on Brexit - but Theresa May vowed again this week that it will never happen.Mr Corbett joins other senior party figures like Mayor of London Sadiq Khan and big union backers like the GMB in actively supporting a second referendum.In response James Cleverly, the Conservative party’s deputy chairman, said: “Instead of trying to make Brexit a success, Labour only want to frustrate the process.“Re-running the referendum would take us all back to square one, and Labour must urgently rule out trying to delay Brexit.“Only the Conservatives have a plan for a deal which will deliver on the result of the referendum by taking back control of our laws, borders and money.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: massive thousand foot spider web covering greek shoreline
story: Hotter than usual weather in the fishing port of Aitoliko, has led to an explosion of Tetragnatha spiders following a boom in mosquitoes - the arachnid army’s favourite food.The scene in the small western Greek town is an arachnophobe’s worst nightmare, with millions of the critters creeping around its nests.The spiders, which have strange elongated bodies, are able to scuttle faster on water than on ground and so prefer their coastal nest.Experts say the webs, which are spun at this time of year but are much larger than normal, are used for mating as well as catching flies. Maria Chatzaki, professor of molecular biology and genetics at Democritus University of Thrace, Greece said heatwaves, sufficient humidity and food paved the way for the booming population.The name Tetragnatha is derived from Greek, tetra — a numerical prefix referring to four and gnatha meaning jaw.They are found all over the world although most thrive in warmer climates in the tropics and subtropics.Commony, they are called stretch spiders because of their eerier elongated body form.When disturbed they will stretch their front legs forward — while they jut their other six legs backwards.This allows them to hide on blades of grass or similar elongated pieces of foliage like twigs and leaves.One of the biggest and most common species is T. extensa.It can be found near lakes, river banks or swamps.Large numbers of iniduals can often be found in reeds, tall grass or minor trees and shrubs.They are so light and nimble that they are able to run over water and chose the waters edge as their preferred habitat.Ms Chatzaki told Newsit.gr: Its as  the spiders are taking advantage of these conditions and are having a kind of a party. “They mate, they reproduce and provide a whole new generation.These spiders are not dangerous for humans and will not cause any damage to the areas flora.The spiders will have their party and will soon die.

title: meghan markle grenfell community kitchen with mum doria ragland prince harry
story: The Duchess of Sussex, 37, beamed as she described the multicultural capital while launching a cookbook written by neighbours of Grenfell Tower disaster victims.Ms Ragland, 62, was heard introducing herself as Megs mom to members of the group.There have been rumours Meghans mum has been looking to move to the UK to be closer to her daughter in recent weeks.Meghan called the book a tremendous labour of love in a speech to volunteers from the kitchen and paid tribute to their community spirit.As Harry and her mother watched on with pride, she described first going to visit the kitchen in January and being overcome by the welcome from the group." data-credit="AFP or licensors" data-sizes="auto" data-img="https:www.thesun/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/NINTCHDBPICT000435488889.jpg?strip=all&ampw=960" height="3444" width="5166"/AFP or licensors15Prince Harry looked on with love as he joined Meghan and Ms Ragland in meeting volunteers from the kitchen" data-credit="AFP or licensors" data-sizes="auto" data-img="https:www.thesun/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/NINTCHDBPICT000435494224-e1537454937657.jpg?strip=all&ampw=960" height="3104" width="4273"/AFP or licensors15 Meghan, Harry and Doria Ragland posed with members of the groupShe said: I had just recently moved to London and I felt so immediately embraced by the women in the kitchen and their warmth and their kindness.On a personal level, I feel so proud to live in a city with so much ersity. There are 12 dferent countries represented just in this room, its pretty outstanding.Everyone embraced this so deeply because its been a passionate project for all of us - and for good reason.Meghan has made a number of secret visits to the kitchen since her first visit as she worked with volunteers on her first solo project as a Royal.The recipes in the book have all been created by cooks from the centre and will support residents affected by the Grenfell fire and others in the West London community.Meghan, 37, helped put the group in touch with a publisher and her Royal Foundation provided assistance with legal and administrative issues.All proceeds will go back to the Hubb and the book is available in stores this week. Hubb means love in Arabic.In her foreword in the book, Meghan said the kitchen was a place for women to laugh, grieve, cry and cook.She added: With the support of dynamic women from all walks of le, we have come together with a united vision to empower other women to share their stories through food.A total of 72 people were killed in the Grenfell Tower disaster in West London in June last year after fire swept through the 24-storey tower block.The 50 dishes in the book are the volunteers own recipes from across Europe, the Middle East, North Africa and the eastern Mediterranean. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tesco new jacks supermarket opening shoppers scramble for bargains
story: Crowds of people queued outside the discount stores in Chatteris, Cambs, and Immingham, Lincs, that Tesco hope will rival Lidl and Aldi.Some shoppers queued outside since 3am hoping to get their hands on a good deal.Pictures showed customers with fully trolleys emptying the aisles of discounted products.Delia Fernandez was one of those who got in line at the Chatteris store early this morning for a bargain.She said: I wanted to see the dferent bargains that theyve got and to have a good look.The 41-year-old, who usually shops at Aldi, added: It all depends on the price and quality of the product.Jeevan Gunaratnam, 48, who emerged with a trolley full of shopping, lives in London but decided to visit Jacks as he was in the area.The medical sales worker said: I occasionally shop in some of the other German stores like Lidl and Aldi so I was curious as I was nearby and thought I would just have a look, and I was really impressed.I think prices are good, I think the whole package Tesco has put together for Jacks is really good and I think it will be a really good addition to the high street.He said he usually shops at Tesco, Lidl and occasionally Waitrose, but added  he had a local Jacks store I think it would influence me to go and buy some things.Obviously theres not the full range but I think for the stuff you need day-to-day its got some really good lines, he said.While retired mechanic Mark Burton, 48, of Chatteris, said: Its more competition, bringing in better prices for the town.The new chain is named after Jack Cohen, who founded Tesco 99 years ago.The UKs biggest supermarket will open 10 to 15 branches of the new chain over the next six months, as it tries to tempt back customers from German discount rivals.The chain also plans to open five  stores which will be bigger than a Tesco Express store but smaller than one of its supermarkets.Stores will have a much smaller amount of products - just 2,600 compared to tens of thousands in normal Tesco branches.Sun Online took a look around the Chatteris store before it opened.Reports that Tesco was planning to open the new stores, with prices to rival Lidl and Aldi, first surfaced in February.

title: pupil spelling i have an account reddit
story: For their homework, the child was given the task of spelling “I have an account”, “she has an account”, “he has an account” and “you have an account”.However, in all the attempts made, the child managed to replace the word “account” with the C-word.The unfortunate mistake was posted to Reddit by user u/punter1414 along with the cheeky caption: “We all have accounts!”Responding to the hilarious clanger, one user wrote: “If at first you don’t succeed…”Another quipped: “You’ve got to a c*** for every possible spelling  you aren’t sure.”One user joked: “One of them is not like the others.”Another Reddit user commented: Nice to know that he has a cant and not a c***.The pupil’s homework containing the C-bomb came after a doting mum baked a cake for her son which looked like it contained the rude word.The cake was supposed to read Good Luck @ Uni but the @ symbol looked more like a fancy c and the i like a t.A picture of the colourful cake was shared on Reddit where users served up a series of tongue-in-cheek replies.One wrote: What sort of person calls their son a c***?To which another replied: One whos delighted to see the little s*** finally leave after eighteen long years.SwissJAmes wrote: Absolute gold - when [your] head says Good Luck @ Uni, but your heart says Get the f*** out of my house.

title: dippy the dinosaur doubles daily visitors on nationwide tour
story: It had been housed at the Natural History Museum in London since 1905, but is now on a three-year tour of the UK, starting with Dorset County Museum in Dorchester, near to the UK's Jurassic Coast.His position in the entrance hall has been filled by the skeleton of a blue whale skeleton, named Hope, which became stranded in 1891 in Wexford Harbour in Ireland.According to BMAG, Dippy attracted more than double the number of visitors than it had during the same period last year.

title: where are we at with brexit your questions answered
story: This is largely because charity rescue vessels are finding it harder and harder to operate because Italy will not let them dock.The migration issue continues to fuel a political crisis across the continent.So it will be a key focus  for EU leaders.The president of the European Council, Donald Tusk, said in a letter to fellow leaders: "The quest to end the migration crisis is a common task of all the member states and EU institutions."If some want to solve the crisis, while others want to use it, it will remain unsolvable."I am hoping that in Salzburg we will be able to put an end to the mutual resentment and  to a constructive approach.":: So what about Brexit? Will it be discussed?Absolutely. To some extent the summit has morphed into a key Brexit staging post.There won't be any formal conclusions or formal changes to the position of the EU - this is an informal summit and the rigidity of EU processes mean they cannot suddenly change course.But there could be subtle indicators of positions being moulded.:: Any key moments to look out for?Yes - at the leaders dinner Theresa May had 10 minutes to state the UK position.It's the first time that the leaders have all met as one since Britain's Chequers proposal  was revealed back in July. She eyeballed her colleagues with a detailed explanation of what that means.She is understood to have told them that neither side can demand the unacceptable of the other and she told them that there would be no second referendum in the UK and no delay to the UK's departure. Towards the end of the summit the 27 remaining members of the EU will meet without Mrs May to discuss Brexit.After that President Tusk and Mrs May will have a 10 minute meeting.There she will hear, in private, what the 27 think, collectively, of her position. Immediately afterwards she will give a news conference.:: Are the two sides really worried about there being a 'no-deal' clf-edge withdrawal?Yes. President Tusk made that very clear in his letter to EU leaders: "Unfortunately, a no deal scenario is still quite possible. But  we all act responsibly, we can avoid a catastrophe."In my sideline chats, EU and UK diplomats are even more blunt. A "no-deal" by accident is unnecessarily possible - each blames the other's intransigence.

title: french president emmanuel macron called
story: NewsFrench President Emmanuel Macron has called Brexiteers 'liars who predicted easy solutions and quit the next day'The French President said Brexit showed other countries that leaving the EU had negative consequencesShare&nbspByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent15:39, 20 SEP 2018Updated15:41, 20 SEP 2018NewsEmmanuel Macron said the Chequers plan cannot be take it or leave it "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEmmanuel Macron has called Brexiteers 'liars who who predicted easy solutions and quit the next day'.  The French president, who has taken a hard stance on preserving the European Union's united front in talks on Britain's departure from the bloc, said Brexit showed other countries that leaving the EU had negative consequences.  It was a good and brave step by the prime minister, Macron told reporters. But we all agreed on this today, the proposals in their current state are not acceptable, especially on the economic side of it, he said. The Chequers plan cannot be take it or leave it, he added.  Those who explain that we can easily live without Europe, that everything is going to be alright, and that it's going to bring a lot of money home are liars, Macron said. It's even more true since they left the day after so as not to have to deal with it, he said, referring to top Brexit proponents.  He said the remaining states would never accept a deal which would damage the EU and its integrity. It comes as European Council president Donald Tusk said the leaders of the remaining 27 EU states agreed the Chequers blueprint for Brexit will not work in its present form. At the end of the two-day informal summit in Salszburg, Mr Tusk said they would decide in October whether there had been sufficient progress in the Brexit talks to call a special summit in November to finalise a deal.  Everybody shared the view that while there are positive elements in the Chequers proposal, the suggested framework for economic co-operation will not work, not least because it is undermining the single market, he said.

title: 14 floor tower swimming pool
story: News14-floor TOWER with swimming pool, tennis court and panoramic views for sale - and it'll make you £35k a yearThe unique property soars above the New Forest and provides breathtaking views of the English countrysideShare&nbspByNicola OakleyHead of Audience12:27, 20 SEP 2018Updated12:53, 20 SEP 2018NewsThe 220ft tower with walled garden and tennis court viewed from above "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf you're in the market for a new home and looking for something unique, a property for sale in the New Forest could tick all the boxes. But you'll need to have a few million pounds lying around. An impressive tower in the New Forest, built in 1886, is up for sale for a handsome &pound3.5million. The Sway Tower, named for its proximity to the village of Sway in Hampshire - and not because of any architectural concerns - reaches a height of 220 feet, spanning 14 floors. It boasts beautul, panoramic views across the New Forest National Park to the Isle of Wight.  While the tower's cupola and its spiral staircase might look like something from a medieval castle, it's actually very homely on the inside and was previously a boutique hotel. On the ground floor is a sitting room, drawing room, dining room, kitchen and conservatory. There's also an indoor swimming pool, tennis court and garage set within a walled garden measuring three quarters of an acre.  Between the first and fourth storeys are four en-suite double bedrooms, each on their own floor. Above this, between floors five and 13, are seven more rooms. Four of them are listed as suitable for conversion into, say, four further double bedrooms . One of the remaining rooms is purely for water storage, while the other three are used by two mobile operators and the emergency services.  While this may sound like an inconvenience, it actually brings in rental income of around &pound35k per year. On top of the tower is the cupola giving breathtaking views across the countryside -  you're fit enough to get up that many stairs.

story: NewsBoxer mum dubbed 'The Secret Assassin' beats 11-year-old schoolgirl - then is fined just £120Kiesha Schofield was left covered in blood, with a fractured nose, bruising and a bloodshot eye, after the shocking attack, her mum saysShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie EvansHannah Smith12:41, 20 SEP 2018NewsKiesha Schofield is pictured with a bloodied face and body "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A boxer mum dubbed 'The Secret Assassin' beat an 11-year-old schoolgirl leaving her 'covered in blood' - but was spared jail with a &pound120 fine.   Kiesha Schofield was assaulted by 28-year-old Jade Binch last year after she reportedly fell out with the mum's daughter, who was a school pal.  She was left with a fractured nose, bruising and a bloodshot eye following the attack, according to her own mother, Tfany Schofield. Tfany, 33, says she reassured Kiesha that Binch would be jailed for the beating, which also allegedly left the youngster with scratches all over her body. But instead, she escaped jail with a fine and a six-month community order.  The attacker, who had been convicted of assault by beating last September, was also given 10 days of rehabilitation activities and told to pay court costs. Now, Kiesha is reportedly too scared to walk to school after repeatedly encountering Binch in the street since the conviction a year ago. Her mum claims Binch 'got away with' the attack. Sharing images of her bloodied daughter, Tfany, from Sutton-in-Ashfield, Nottinghamshire, said: You can see the state Kiesha was in from the pictures. She had blood all over her face and was bruised on her head and body. She claimed Binch fractured Kiesha's nose and left her with scratches over her body and bruises on her back and arms where she had been kicked. She had a bruised and blood shot eye which took a long time to heal, she said.  However, Binch claimed that the injuries obtained by the young girl were not linked to the incident and that Tfany's claims were not true. The Crown Prosecution Service  confirmed the images showing Kiesha with a bloodied face, damaged nose and bruising were used as evidence in the case. Tfany continued: I was livid. I wanted to do the same to her that she'd done to Kiesha but common sense kicked in. I knew I needed to show Kiesha that you follow the right processes. I knew I couldn't retaliate. I kept reassuring her: 'She'll definitely get prison time for this'. When she was given the fine and no jail sentence, I couldn't believe it. The judge who also watched the CCTV footage in court gave her a fine - how is that justice for attacking a minor? An online video appears to show Binch training in a boxing ring three years ago. The man who shared the footage claimed to have trained her for four years. Many commenters praised her 'hook', while Binch bragged that she was a 'wolf not a sheep'.  Kiesha and Binch's daughter had been playing in a group in March 2017 when they reportedly fell out. According to Tfany, Binch then approached the schoolgirl after being alerted to the row by her daughter. She then assaulted her, allegedly leaving her hospitalised for the day. Tfany claimed: Kiesha and Jade's daughter were the best of friends. They'd been at my house for dinner just before the attack happened. There was a big group of them out and Jade's daughter had fallen out with her boyfriend. Kiesha went over to tell him everything would be alright and Jade's daughter just said 'I'm going to tell my mum.' Kiesha rang me panicking saying her friend's mum was 'coming down to get her'. I just reassured her, thinking 'what mum was going to do anything to a child?' The rest of the group started walking to the shop and Jade then pulled up and got out of the car and assaulted her. As the youngster lay injured on the pavement, concerned passersby ran to her rescue and called the emergency services.  Tfany, a cleaning supervisor, and her partner were forced to rush out of work after a friend called them in a panic. The mum said: Kiesha was in [the hospital] for a few hours because they needed to keep her an eye on her due to her head. She claims that her daughter is now so scared that she won't even leave the house without her brother. Kiesha doesn't go out anymore, Tfany said. There's a shop at the top of the road and she won't go without her brother. She added: Kiesha does nothing and has got a very negative outlook on le. A year and half later, my daughter is still seeing a counsellor, still has flashbacks of that awful night. She now has a barrier up which she will not lower and she don't understand how someone could do what this evil person did and yet get away with it.

story: NewsMeghan Markle takes her mum to work as she launches new charity cookbook at Kensington PalaceIt is the first official engagement Doria Ragland has been on since her daughter became a fully-fledged member of the royal familyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth15:17, 20 SEP 2018Updated16:21, 20 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/watch-meghan-arrives-kensington-palace-13279466,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle took her mum to work today as she launched her new charity cookbook. The event, at Kensington Palace, is the first official engagement Doria Ragland has been on since her daughter became a fully-fledged member of the royal family. The Duchess of Sussex is marking the launch of her first solo project Together: Our Community Cookbook -a charity cookbook in aid of those affected by the Grenfell Tower tragedy. The 37-year-old is joined by Prince Harry, 34, for the book launch, which is taking place on the palace grounds. She smiled warmly as she stepped out of a vehicle with her mother, while wearing a Tuxe top, Misha Nonoo skirt and Smythson blue coat. In a touching moment, Ms Ragland said I'm Meg's mum as she introduced herself to the woman behind the Grenfell cookbook. She then hugged and told the women: 'I'm just as excited as you are.  I'm so glad I can put the face with the recipes. I'm going to make everything.  The power of women. We make things happen. We're curious, we say yes, we show up. I'm inspired.    Baroness Gail Rebuck, chair of publisher Penguin Random House, told Ms Ragland she must feel “very proud” of the duchess and her work on the cookbook, to which she replied head over heels. The former Suits actress had met a group of women during secret visits to the community who had started cooking for people around them whose lives had been destroyed by the disaster. She became close with the team at the Hubb Community Kitchen in the Al Manaar Muslim Cultural Heritage Centre in West London. When she discovered they could only open two days a week because of funding, an idea was born and now months later she has launched their charity cookbook. As well as promoting the fundraiser with a sweet video, she's written a very personal three-page foreword for the book. She speaks about her experiences meeting the women at the Hubb Community Kitchen and why she believes food is so important. The royal spoke passionately for around three minutes without notes about the project in her speech as Prince Harry and her mother looked on proudly. The Duchess of Sussex said: I'm so privileged to know you. Working on this project for the past nine months has been a tremendous labour of love.   speech  I have just recently moved to London and I felt so immediately embraced by the women in the kitchen, by your kindness and to be in this city and be in this room and see how multi-cultural it was.  On a personal level I feel so proud to live in a city with so much ersity. This whole country is represented by the people in the kitchen. It's pretty outstanding. There's so many people to thank - I'm extremely grateful because this is my first project and I appreciate your support. It truly took a village to see this through. Everyone has embraced this so fully because it has been a passion project for us all. As I said this is more than a cook book and what I mean by that is the power of food is more than just the meal itself it is the story behind it. And when you get to know the story behind the recipe, you get to know the person behind it and help us celebrate what connects us rather than ides us. That is the ethos of Together. Women of the Hubb Community Kitchen are showcasing their own personal recipes featured in the cookbook, many of which have been handed down through generations.  The duchess is joining them as they cook the dishes and assist with the preparations, before the group and the duke and duchess sit to enjoy the freshly made food with their guests. Dishes were handed out to those attending in the outdoor reception at the palace where there were long tables decorated with brightly coloured flowers. Homemade dishes including coconut chicken curry, aubergine masala and a range of chapatis and sharing dips, as well as caramelised plum upside-down cake, and spiced mint tea.  Meghan continued in her speech: Thank you so much for letting me be part of this and letting me be on this adventure with you and I’m so excited to see the projects we will continue to do in your community and also how you will inspire people globally by sharing your stories and your recipes. It's so impactful. You can see that in just a few days alone what's happened and the book's not out yet. What you have been able to do is a testament to what that means to people. I'm so proud of you. So on that note I know that some of you have started eating, as you should. I'd be the last one to want to let the food get cold so please enjoy your beautul lunch and give another round of applause for the Hubb Community Kitchen. Thank you.  Meghan, her mother and Prince Harry made their way around four food stations, with the duchess helping to cook along the way. Ahlam Saeid had prepared a huge bowl of green rice at the first stop, to which the duchess added fresh mint and olive oil. Ms Ragland asked the cooks questions about the ingredients, while one of the cooks promised to set food aside for the royal couple. The duchess told her: Oh thank you, I'll take that home and have it for dinner. Meghan appeared to be a dab hand in the kitchen as she confidently flipped chapatis and turned koftas on the grill. Meanwhile the duke was several steps behind, chatting to guests and watching his we proudly. Following lunch, the trio posed for a group photo with the women of the kitchen and their families then stayed to talk to them.    Kensington Palace previously shared a touching video of Meghan working in the kitchen and chatting with the women to promote the new project. She also wrote an emotional three-page foreword for the book, which can now be pre-ordered on Amazon for just &pound9.99. In it she recalls the moment she heard about the Grenfell fire when she was working in Canada, and how she wanted to help. She writes about visiting the kitchen when she was getting used to le in London with Prince Harry and the incredible women she met. Details of her favourite meals are also shared including collard greens, black-eyed peas and cornbread, which reminds her of her childhood.  The duchess went to meet those affected by the Grenfell disaster at least twice at the beginning of the year, including a trip to the Al Manaar community mosque, which lies in the shadow of the charred shell of Grenfell Tower. She was without Prince Harry but was accompanied by a royal protection officer and one of the prince’s aides. The visits were compared to many made by her late mother-in-law Princess Diana, who often carried out charity work in secret. Speaking at the time, a leading Grenfell community member said: Meghan's visits mean so much to us. She has a special place in our hearts. A royal source added: Ms Markle has regularly been making private visits to organisations as she gets to know the charity sector.

Jurors were shown footage of Mohammed Abdul, 21, allegedly driving his Suzuki Vitara past bouncers and into revellers. CCTV footage appears to show the vehicle coursing down an alleyway packed with clubbers before later ploughing into the venue itself. From a camera inside Blake's in Gravesend, Kent, the vehicle's front lights can be seen getting closer and closer as dancers mingle, unaware the Suzuki is hurtling towards them.  One man can then be seen spread-eagled on the bonnet, swept off his feet as the Suzuki rams into him from behind. Others are seen fleeing to safety as security guards appear in hot pursuit of the car, shortly before midnight on March 17 this year. The car can be seen reversing, its registration plate hanging off at an angle, as patrons stagger to get to their feet. Some clubbers can be seen appearing to swarm the vehicle and showering it with a volley of thumps, while others look visibly distressed in the corner of the nightclub.  Abdul is on trial at Maidstone Crown Court for attempted murder over the incident which left eight people injured. The court heard he had been ejected from the venue at around 11.40pm for being too drunk. His trial was told that while in a rage and acting aggressively, he threatened bouncers, telling doorman Peter Muro: If I can't come in I'm going to come back and shut this place down and kill you guys. Abdul ed in his vehicle around 10 minutes later and drove at speed down a narrow alleyway by the side of the club, with door staff and clubbers jumping or being pulled out of the way, prosecutor Simon Taylor said.  The alleyway housed a marquee attached to the club with a dance floor and DJ booth, and it was filled with revellers there to see grime rapper Giggs. Abdul, of Deptford, south-east London, accepts he was the driver of the vehicle and has admitted causing serious injury by dangerous driving, jurors heard. But he denies two counts of attempting to murder persons in the vicinity of the club and an alternative charge of attempting to cause grievous bodily harm with intent.

The deadly storm created hellish conditions for pilots across the country as fierce crosswinds tested their nerves. Captains are trained for this kind of weather and this pilot - responsible for dozens of passengers - made a perfect landing at Manchester Airport despite the nasty conditions.  Strong winds rocked the aircraft from side to side as it touched down, the Manchester Evening News reports.   The video footage, published by Aviation Up Close, shows the easyJet pilot was undeterred by the bad weather, bringing passengers smoothly to safety on the runway.  In another incident, British holidaymakers vomited and sobbed during violent turbulence as Ali hit a plane travelling to Glasgow from Ibiza.  Two people were killed when the brutal storm hit on Wednesday and damaged property, brought down trees and caused travel disruption. Winds peaked at 102.2mph on the Tay Road Bridge in Dundee, according to bridge equipment.  A Swiss holidaymaker was killed after the caravan she was in was blown down a rocky incline and smashed to pieces on the beach below in County Galway, while a worker in a forest park in County Armagh died after he was hit by a tree. The woman, named locally as Elvira Ferraii and said to have been aged in her 50s, was reported to have been staying at the remote beauty spot in Clden ecoBeach Camping and Caravan Park for a number of weeks. The man, aged in his 20s, was working on behalf of public utility Northern Ireland Water in Slieve Gullion Forest Park. A co-worker was injured. A number of others were injured by falling trees.  In Cheshire, a woman was seriously injured after a tree fell onto her car, and in the Highlands a man had to be rescued after becoming trapped under a digger in a river in the village of Rogart. More than 250,000 homes and businesses across the island of Ireland were at one stage without power as a result of Storm Ali, with emergency workers battling dficult conditions as wind speeds peaked during the afternoon. Ireland's electricity network, ESB Networks, said thousands of homes, businesses and farms have been left without power - with the most impacted in Cavan, Sligo, Donegal, Castlebar and Galway. In Northern Ireland, thousands of homes and businesses were without power as gusts of 70mph caused signicant damage.

The second named storm of the season was christened today - just hours before it hit Ireland with heavy rain.  The Met Office's official warning for the UK said : Storm Bronagh brings potential for very strong winds on Thursday evening and overnight into Friday morning.  Injuries and danger to le from flying debris are possible, it added. Road, rail, air and ferry services may be affected.  Met Eireann, Ireland's national weather service, has put in place a weather warning saying 40mm of rain could dump down in parts, the Irish Mirror reported .  It said: Rain will be persistent and heavy at times especially during the afternoon with risk of spot flooding. Totals of 25 to 40mm expected, highest values likely near coast.  The Met Office- who share storm names with Met Eireann - officially named the front, saying: Today's weather system has been named #StormBronagh. Yellow warnings are in force, with heavy rain and strong winds across parts of #England and #Wales. Irish weather expert Alan O'Reilly has predicted a third storm of the week could reach Ireland on Sunday.  He wrote on the Carlow Weather Facebook page: The UK Met Office have named #StormBronagh which is bringing us rain today and will intensy as it reaches Wales and England bringing strong winds and rain there.  And now that the UK Met Office have named #StormBronagh for Today  the system on Sunday does materialize and reaches naming levels it will be #StormCallum.  This comes after Storm Ali battered Ireland on Wednesday with gusts of up to 130km/h. Earlier this month, the new storm names for this winter were revealed and there's some Irish classics. Saoirse, Bronagh, Niamh and Deirdre all feature on the list of 21, which was announced at midnight. This is the fourth year Met Eireann have teamed up with the Met Office in the UK to jointly run the 'Name our Storms' scheme. It was first introduced in 2015 in a bid to raise awareness of severe conditions before they hit the country.
